newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia's Samper takes ax to bureaucracy.
newsitem.headline: Colombia's Samper takes ax to bureaucracy.

text.p: Colombian President Ernesto Samper said on Thursday he was cutting more than 3,000 government jobs to plug a gaping fiscal deficit and "debureaucratize the state."

Samper, who announced the job cuts in a speech at the National School of Public Administration, said they would affect employees in a dozen ministries and state-run offices and 17 embassies and consulates worldwide.
He also said a freeze on new hiring by the central government would take effect on July 1 and some government offices, including the National Board of Tourism, were being shut down completely.

In a warning to the country's bureaucrats, Samper said the job cuts and streamlining of government offices were the first of many steps toward a "rationalization" of government services that would be accomplished before he left office in August 1998.
"We're going to begin once and for all to fight bureaucracy," he said. "I'm going to hand over a clean and orderly house," he added, alluding to the end of his term.
Samper estimated the job cuts and elimination of some government offices would save up to $100 million a year.

He said he was creating one new government post, however, before the July 1 hiring freeze. He said he would soon appoint a special ombudsman to investigate what critics describe as the many human rights violations committed by the military-run National Police.
